docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I applaud Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan aggressively to seek out poor children and adults to enroll in Medicaid (news analysis, June 19), but does he realize how much collective suffering, aggravation and anxiety would have been spared had he empathized sooner?
docs.abstract: Vincente Garcia-Delgado letter on June 19 article holds Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani should have acted sooner to enroll poor in Medicaid

docs.lead_paragraph: At first, it seemed that it might be a statistical blip. But no, public health officials said today, it is a definite and striking trend: Massachusetts, they believe, has become the first state where more babies are born to women over the age of 30 than under it. State figures made public this week showed that among Massachusetts women who gave birth in 1998, about 43,000 were 30 or over, and about 39,000 were under 30. That contrasted sharply with state figures as recent as those from 1990, when only about 37,000 women 30 and over gave birth, compared with 55,000 under 30. In 1980, the number of new mothers under 30 was nearly triple the new mothers 30 and over.

headline.main: Massachusetts Is Set Apart In Ratio of Older Mothers

docs.abstract: Massachusetts public health officials say statistics suggest state may be first in which more babies are born to women over age of 30 than under it; statistics show among women who gave birth in 1998, about 43,000 were 30 or over, and that about 39,000 were under 30; in 1990, only 37,000 women 30 years or older gave birth, compared with 55,000 under 30; in 1980, number of new mothers under 30 was nearly triple new mothers 30 and over; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Whirling around 180 degrees, the House today voted to allow the Department of Veterans Affairs to transfer $4 million to the Justice Department to help in its wide-ranging lawsuit against the tobacco industry. The extraordinary about-face took place on a voice vote and occurred less than 24 hours after the lawmakers had specifically voted to ban such a transfer, arguing that the Justice Department was taking away medical benefits from veterans to pay for its litigation.

headline.main: House Reverses Itself on a Suit Over Smoking

docs.abstract: House of Representatives reverses itself and votes to allow Department of Veterans Affairs to transfer $4 million to Justice Department to help agency in its wide-ranging lawsuit against tobacco industry; about-face comes less than day after lawmakers specifically voted to ban such transfer, arguing that department was taking away medical benefits from veterans to pay for litigation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today proposed increasing Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes and other health care providers, as evidence grew that cuts made in 1997 had harmed the quality of care around the country. Mr. Clinton asked Congress to increase payments to providers by $21 billion in the next five years and by $40 billion over 10 years.

headline.main: Changing Tack, Clinton Urges Increasing Medicare Payments

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton proposes increasing Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes and other health care providers, as evidence grows that cuts made in 1997 have harmed quality of care nationwide; asks Congress to increase payments to providers by $21 billion in next five years and by $40 billion over 10 years; proposals represent abrupt reversal by administration, which asked Congress in budget request five months ago to cut payments to providers by $30 billion over next 10 years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Relabeling bad habits as mental disorders is bad social policy and dangerous to society. ''Procrastination, impulsiveness, disorganization, hyperactivity, lack of motivation and an inability to manage time,'' you report (Workplace section, June 14), are the key symptoms of the ''biochemical imbalances in the brain'' now called adult attention disorder.
docs.abstract: Dr Nathaniel S Lehrman letter on June 14 article questions relabeling of bad habits as adult attention disorder

docs.lead_paragraph: THE REPUBLICANS BUSH TOPS $90 MILLION MARK -- Gov. George W. Bush's presidential campaign continues to shatter fund-raising records, topping the $90 million mark when receipts for May are included. But most of the money has already been spent and the Texas governor continues to beat the bushes for more. Campaign officials announced yesterday that Mr. Bush raised $6 million in May and spent $4.9 million, leaving him with $7.1 million in the bank. Vice President Al Gore reported that he had raised only $587,802 in May, and had spent $1.3 million. He was left with $8.2 million, out of $37 million raised over all during the campaign. Mr. Gore expects to qualify for $15 million in federal matching funds, bringing his total preconvention fund to the $40.5 million spending cap placed on candidates who accept federal money. Mr. Bush, who is not accepting federal money, expects to spend nearly twice as much before the Republican National Convention, which starts on July 31. After the conventions, candidates must stop fund-raising and will be given $67.6 million in federal funds to spend on the general election. (NYT)
docs.abstract: Campaign Briefing: George W Bush's presidential campaign continues to shatter fund-raising records, topping $90-million mark; AFL-CIO warns that 'truth squad' will appear at events to talk about problems in Bush's state of Texas; John Hagelin, physicist who founded Natural Law Party, challenges Patrick Buchanan for Reform Party presidential nomination and right to spend party's $12.6 million in federal campaign money; Bush vows to compete all out for California's 54 electoral votes, although new Golden State Poll gives Gore 11-point lead in state; Democrats unveil ads aimed at black and Hispanic voters (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK LAKE GEORGE: MRS. CLINTON DEMURS In February, when Hillary Rodham Clinton was considering a Senate race against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, she exuberantly suggested that she and the mayor crisscross the state, debating where they stopped. But when she was asked yesterday if she would favor marathon debates with Mr. Giuliani's replacement, Representative Rick A. Lazio, she was noncommittal. She said she had already accepted two debates. Had her views changed with Mr. Giuliani out of the race? Joseph Reilly, the president of the broadcasters group, pulled Mrs. Clinton away before she could answer. Adam Nagourney (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: When word got out recently that two radiology centers in Portland, Ore., were offering a new screening test for the early detection of lung cancer, the response was overwhelming. Smokers and former smokers jammed the centers' phones, demanding the simple, painless test that can find lung cancers so tiny that they can be snipped out and, doctors hope, the patients cured. In a single day, more than 300 people called one of the centers, Epic Imaging. ''I got in at 6:30 that morning and didn't get off the phone until 6:30 that night,'' said Melanie Haymond, a marketing director there.

headline.main: Lung Cancer Test Is Much in Demand, But Benefit Is Murky

docs.abstract: Increasing number of radiologists are advertising and performing new lung cancer screening test done with powerful new spiral CT X-ray scanner, despite uncertainty over whether more people will be harmed than helped by test since scanner's effectiveness has never been rigorously tested; scanner can detect tumor many times small than those found with conventional chest X-ray; Dr Claudia L Henschke, researcher at New York Presbyterian Hospital who pioneered use of scanner, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I'M thinking of turning off my computer, silencing my cell phone and going to the movies. I have no idea what film I'll see, but that isn't the point. What matters is that the theater will be dark and cool and virtually empty -- because it will be the middle of the day, when I should really be at work. I never once played hooky as a child. I'm somewhat embarrassed to admit that I never even thought of it. Maybe I am compensating for that as an adult (or maybe this comes up on days when I don't necessarily want to be an adult), but I get the periodic urge to sneak out once in a while.
docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin's Life's Work column on playing 'hooky' in middle of the day from her job to do something entertaining like go to the movies; says growing number of companies are allowing employees to play occasional hooky; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee, the panel responsible for Medicare legislation, plan to introduce a bill on Tuesday to establish prescription drug benefits for the elderly, even as senior Senate Republicans appear to be floundering in efforts to develop a proposal of their own. The Democrats' initiative, orchestrated by Senator Bob Graham of Florida, comes just a day before the House Ways and Means Committee is to start voting on legislation to authorize outpatient drug benefits under Medicare, the federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled.

headline.main: Senate Democrats to Introduce Plan for Medicare Drug Benefits

docs.abstract: Five Democrats on Senate Finance Committee, panel responsible for Medicare legislation, will introduce bill to establish prescription drug benefits for elderly, even as senior Senate Republicans appear to be floundering in efforts to develop proposal of their own; initiative,orchestrated by Sen Bob Graham, comes day before House Ways and Means Committee will begin voting on legislation authorizing outpatient drug benefits under Medicare (M)
